issue.title: Broken Effects of some basic_string::compare functions in terms of basic_string_view

discussion.p: Some basic_string::compare functions are specified in terms of a non-existing basic_string_view constructor, namely p3,

blockquote.pre: return basic_string_view<charT, traits>(this.data(), pos1, n1).compare(sv, pos2, n2);

discussion.p:
because there doesn't exist a basic_string_view constructor with three arguments.
Albeit this can be easily fixed by a proper combination of the existing constructor

blockquote.pre: constexpr basic_string_view(const charT* str, size_type len);
constexpr basic_string_view substr(size_type pos = 0, size_type n = npos) const;

discussion.p: it should be decided whether adding the seemingly natural constructor

blockquote.pre: constexpr basic_string_view(const charT* str, size_type pos, size_type n);

discussion.p:
could simplify matters. A counter argument for this addition might be, that basic_string doesn't provide this constructor either.
Another problem is related to the specification of p4, which attempts to call a non-existing basic_string_view::compare overload that would match the signature:

blockquote.pre: constexpr int compare(basic_string_view str, size_type pos1, size_type n1) const;

discussion.p: Marshall to investigate using P/R vs. adding the missing constructor.
Marshall reports that P/R is better. Status to Tentatively Ready

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N4606.

blockquote.p: [Drafting note: The wording changes below are for the same part of the standard as . However, they do not conflict. This one changes the "Effects" of the routine, while the other changes the definition. — end drafting note]

blockquote.pre: int compare(size_type pos1, size_type n1, basic_string_view<charT, traits> sv) const;
return basic_string_view<charT, traits>(this.data(), size()).substr(pos1, n1).compare(sv,.substr(pos2, n2));
